item.title:
Spike raster plots can be frustrating to work with if you make them as vector art. If you work with Python, these issues can be solved by using two tricks described in the thread below and in code shared to our lab's GitHub repo. #opensource #python
https://t.co/hJlsi6nss9 https://t.co/4ZE43t4jPk

item.content:encoded: Spike raster plots can be frustrating to work with if you make them as vector art. If you work with Python, these issues can be solved by using two tricks described in the thread below and in code shared to our lab's GitHub repo. #opensource #python https://t.co/hJlsi6nss9 https://t.co/4ZE43t4jPk

item.title: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.
item.description: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.
item.content:encoded: The first thing to do is to rasterize the spikes directly as they are plotted and then save the figure as an SVG with dpi=600. This side steps having to make two versions of the figure, one as a SVG or PDF for text and another as a PNG for the spikes.

item.title: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd
item.description: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd
item.content:encoded: Just add "rasterized=True" to the matplotlib command that you use to plot the spikes. Our lab uses modified code for plotting spike rasters from this gist: https://t.co/Ds5JLyhqZd

item.title: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8
item.description: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8
item.content:encoded: The second thing is to use the scour library to "scrub" the SVG file. This library is amazing for anyone using Inkscape. No more need to import PDFs or use the deep ungroup function before you get to work. https://t.co/vgyqCWfvB8

item.title: This stuff might be common knowledge, but it was news to me. We've been working on a complex figure with a bunch of rasters for a new manuscript and these tricks have made things a lot easier. Hope this is helpful for others.
